block.para: The concept of a function is properly introduced within the context of set theory. Here we describe in pictorial terms how it may be interpreted as transforming objects.

In the graphic below the blob B on the left gets transformed into the object Z on the right. In the process, each point of B gets relocated to some point of Z. It is this act of relocating points of B to points of Z which is described by a function.

Let's now analyze how a function transforms an object. A function f from B to Z, denoted f\from B\to Z sends each x of B to some z in Z. Note that there must be exactly one z to which x gets transformed. We write
to express that f transforms x into z. Thus f ‘knows’ for each x in B to which point in Z it must be relocated. Accordingly, we think of f as executing the given transformation.
It is allowed that two or more distinct points of B get transformed into the same point of Z. In the graphic above this applies to the points labeled u_1 and u_2. We therefore have the equation
